# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

```julia
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Step 1: Filter the DataFrame to include only Audi cars with model "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_filtered = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)

    # Step 2: Create a new column named `audi_a4_type` with value `true` for all rows in the filtered DataFrame
    df_filtered = hcat(df_filtered, fill(true, size(df_filtered)[1], 1), :auto)
    df_filtered = rename!(df_filtered, ["audi_a4_type" => "audi_a4_type"])

    # Step 3: Return the filtered and modified DataFrame
    return df_filtered
end

# Test the function with provided data
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])

# Call the function with the provided data
result = audi_filter(df_cars)

# Check the result
expected_result = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series"],
    audi_a4_type=[true, true, true])

# Compare the result with the expected result
result == expected_result  # This should return `true` if the function works correctly
```
